text: With average temperatures above freezing levels,
real snowflakes are most certainly not blanketing
sochie slopes at the 2014 Winter Olympics.
And soâ€¦ we rely on science
to to keep the games alive.
Producing artificial snow is not as simple as
grinding up big blocks ice and spraying it around.
Snow goes to quite a process in nature in here
on the ground we have to make sure we mimic
certain conditions perfectly to make it happen.
When snow forms naturally, tiny droplets
of liquid water in a cloud, freeze
and form a crystal around particular
matter like a speck of dust.
That piece in particular is a so-called
nucleating agent, which acts as a seed for
all the ice crystal growth action.
Once the first ice crystal forms hordes
of other water molecules freeze to the
surface is ice making up a single snowflake.
After the flake is heavy enough it breaks
through the stronghold of the air
that holds it up in the clouds
and gently floats down to the ground.
To make artificial snow, water cooled to
just above its freezing point is pumped under
high-pressure with the nozzles of a snow gun.
This thing blast water in nucleating
agents 20 to 30 feet in the air.
The tiny nozzles in the snow guns break
up the water into a super fine mist and
fans of compressed air help keep water
particles afloat much longer to make sure
the freezer for hit the ground.
Also, the compressed air expands when released
thus dropping its temperature alongside
the temperature of the water particles.
Another important component to making
snow is to make sure that you've got the
right combination of temperature and humidity.
Lower humidity means that snow can
be formed at higher temperatures.
With untreated water a temperature of
about eighteen degrees Fahrenheit more
about negative eight degrees Celsius is needed.
If the temperature is it cold enough
added materials are used for nucleation.
Just like with real snow, nucleating agents
are extremely important for artificial snow.
So in modern snow guns there are a lot of
different types used including silver iodide
or proteins made by special bacteria.
These additives are crucial starting points
for ice crystal formation, especially
when the temperatures are above freezing,
like they are in sochi. So as you can see
making snow is a pretty complex endeavor.
Alongside benefiting slopes it also benefits fans.
Watching winter sports in above freezing weather
can definitely be considered a modern luxury.
